meanings.def: to hand something to somebody so that they can look at it, use it or keep it for a time
examples: give something to somebody Give the letter to your mother when you've read it.
She gave her ticket to the woman at the check-in desk.
give somebody something Give your mother the letter.
They were all given a box to carry.

meanings.def: to hand something to somebody as a present; to allow somebody to have something as a present
examples: give somebody something What are you giving your father for his birthday?
She was given a huge bunch of flowers.
Did you give the waiter a tip?
give something to somebody She gave a couple of pounds to the beggar.
give (something) We all agreed not to give presents this year.
They say it's better to give than to receive.

meanings.def: to provide somebody with something
examples: give somebody something They were all thirsty so I gave them a drink.
Give me your name and address.
We've been given a 2 per cent pay increase.
I was hoping you would give me a job.
He was given a new heart in a five-hour operation.
Give me some time to decide.
We should at least give him the opportunity to explain why he did this.
This should give you some idea of the extent of the problem.
Can you give us some sense of exactly what is at stake here?
We'll give you all the help we can.
She wants a job that gives her more responsibility.
Can I give you a ride to the station?
I'll give you (= allow you to have) ten minutes to prepare your answer.
Don't give me any of that backchat (= don't be rude).
give something to somebody He gives Italian lessons to his colleagues.
The reforms should give a better chance to the less able children.
give something She gave some helpful advice.
She gives the impression of being very busy.
I was asked to give evidence at the trial.
She gave me some medicine that sent me off to sleep.
Let me give you a word of advice.
The dark glasses gave him an air of mystery.
This shampoo will give your hair a nice healthy sheen.
We want to give you the best possible care.
They couldn't give me any more information.
He just left. He wouldn't give a reason.
The police did not give any details of the attack.

meanings.def: to pay money to a charity, etc., to help people
examples: We need your help—please give generously.
give to something They both gave regularly to charity.
give something I gave a small donation.
give something to something A lot of people give money to good causes.

meanings.def: to pay in order to have or do something
examples: give somebody something I'll give you £100 and not a penny more!
give somebody something for something How much will you give me for the car?
give something I'd give anything to see him again.
give something for something I gave £50 for the lot.

meanings.def: used with a noun to describe a particular action, giving the same meaning as the related verb
examples: give something She gave a shrug of her shoulders (= shrugged).
He turned to us and gave a big smile (= smiled broadly).
She looked up from her work and gave a yawn (= yawned).
He gave a loud cry (= cried out loudly) and fell to the floor.
Her work has given pleasure to (= pleased) millions of readers.
give somebody something He gave her a kiss (= kissed her).
I have to admit that the news gave us a shock (= shocked us).
He gave me a suspicious look (= looked at me suspiciously).

meanings.def: to produce a particular feeling in somebody
examples: All that driving has given me a headache.
Go for a walk. It'll give you an appetite.

meanings.def: to make a phone call to somebody
examples: Give me a call tomorrow.
(British English) I'll give you a ring.

meanings.def: to judge somebody/something to be of a particular standard
examples: give somebody/something sth She had given the assignment an A.
I give it ten out of ten for originality.
give something He virtually never gives a grade of less than C.
give something to somebody/something I gave top marks to her essay.

meanings.def: to pass an illness onto somebody and make them ill
examples: give somebody something You've given me your cold.
give something to somebody She'd given the bug to all her colleagues.

meanings.def: to make somebody suffer a particular punishment
examples: give somebody something The judge gave him a nine-month suspended sentence.
give something to somebody We discussed what punishment should be given to the boys.

meanings.def: if you give a party, you organize it and invite people
examples: We're giving a party to celebrate our silver wedding.

meanings.def: to perform something in public
examples: give something He gave a rousing performance of the Bob Marley song.
She gave a reading from her latest volume of poetry.
The President will be giving a press conference this afternoon.
give something to somebody She gave a fine speech to the waiting crowd.

meanings.def: to use time, energy, etc. for somebody/something
examples: give somebody/something sth I gave the matter a lot of thought.
give something to somebody/something I gave a lot of thought to the matter.
The government has given top priority to reforming the tax system.

meanings.def: to predict that something will last a particular length of time
examples: That marriage won't last. I'll give them two years at the outside.

meanings.def: to say that a player or the ball is in a particular position or that a goal has been scored
examples: give somebody/something + adj. The umpire gave the ball out.
give something The ref gave the goal.

meanings.def: to bend or stretch under pressure
examples: The branch began to give under his weight.
(figurative) We can't go on like this—something's got to give.

meanings.def: to agree to change your mind or give up some of your demands
examples: You're going to have to give a little.

meanings.def: used to tell somebody that you do not accept what they say
examples: ‘I didn't have time to do it.’ ‘Oh, don't give me that!’

meanings.def: to be willing, in a relationship, to accept what somebody else wants and to give up some of what you want
examples: You're going to have to learn to give and take.

meanings.def: to react with equal force when somebody attacks or criticizes you
examples: She can give as good as she gets.

meanings.def: to show your approval of somebody by clapping your hands
examples: Give it up for Ed Sheeran!

meanings.def: used to say that you prefer a particular thing or person to the one that has just been mentioned
examples: We don't go out much. Give me a quiet night in front of the TV any day!

meanings.def: if something is correct give or take a particular amount, it is approximately correct
examples: It'll take about three weeks, give or take a day or so.

meanings.def: to make somebody believe/understand something
examples: I was given to understand that she had resigned.

meanings.def: to severely punish or criticize somebody for doing something wrong
examples: My son was rude to my friends so I gave him what for.

meanings.def: used to ask people to drink a toast to somebody
examples: Ladies and gentlemen, I give you Geoff Ogilby!

meanings.def: used when you are admitting that something is true
what is happening?; what is the news?

idioms.def: used to tell somebody that you do not accept what they say
examples: ‘I didn't have time to do it.’ ‘Oh, don't give me that!’

examples: You're going to have to learn to give and take.

meanings.def: the ability of something to bend or stretch under pressure
examples: The shoes may seem tight at first, but the leather has plenty of give in it.

meanings.def: the quality of being willing to accept what somebody else wants and give up some of what you want
examples: If the dispute is to be resolved there must be some give and take.
Marriage is a give-and-take relationship.

meanings.def: an exchange of words or ideas
examples: to encourage a lively give and take
